Identifying Characteristics: Gray or tan frog marked with seven to twenty-one irregular rectangular dark brown spots that are oriented in two columns down its back
Distinctive rectangular spots of the pickerel frog may blend together to form a long rectangle along the back
Prominent dorsolateral ridges that are unbroken
Orange or yellow flash pattern found on the inner surface of the hind legs (frog must be picked up to examine this—legs cover the coloration)
Size: Adults can be between 4-8cm long
Biology: Breeding season lasts from March to May (usually beginning as Leopard Frogs are concluding their breeding activity)
Males find mates by calling out a low-pitched snore
Egg masses of 2000-3000 eggs are typically laid in well-vegetated areas and are often difficult to locate (masses superficially resemble those of wood frogs)
Eggs are multicolored—dark brown on top and cream colored on the bottom
Egg masses adhere to woody or herbaceous vegetation, varying in depth from a few centimeters below the surface to 4 feet deep
Eggs usually hatch in 11–21 days—temperature dependent
Tadpole stage lasts about 3 months until they metamorphose into frogs (initially still have tails when they emerge from the water)
Females are typically larger and darker than males
Habitat: Along the edges of streams, lakes, rivers, and flooded ditches
Northern Species: Live near cold, clear water
Prefer rocky ravines, bogs and meadow streams
Can be found around lakes and rivers that are heavily wooded
Southern Species: Prefers warmer waters—like those of the Coastal Plain and floodplain swamps
Diet: Insects, spiders, sawfly larvae and other invertebrates
Range: Southern Canada and southeastern United States
